awd_titl_txt: Wave Loads and Structural Fragility Behind Impermeable and Permeable Obstacles
awd_abstract_narration:
Inundation from storm waves and tsunamis has caused great damage to buildings and infrastructure both in the United States and worldwide.  Reduction of damage and overall risk mitigation remain priorities for coastal communities now and in the future, but these goals are in some ways limited by engineering design and analysis tools.  Damage from storm waves and tsunamis is well known to be diminished behind structures or vegetation, but it has proven surprisingly difficult to translate this general knowledge to specific guidelines and standards for engineers and planners.  This project will use theory, numerical models, and results from field and laboratory measurements to investigate the degree of damage reduction behind sheltering structures. Two notable features of this analysis will be the consideration of sheltering obstacle degradation during an event, and a framework for probabilistic analysis that will allow design for different levels of risk.  Useful quantification of loading for sheltered structures will remove a major impediment to accurate design and planning for inundation events.  This project will help to improve load estimates in ways that will be directly applicable to many instances of engineering design.

Unlike hazards such as earthquakes, Inundation Event (IE) loading from storm waves or tsunamis can vary on scales of O(10m), and is greatly affected by the surrounding natural and built environments.  Uncertainty in computing the local hazard and local loading remains the greatest obstacle in determining fragility for planning and structural design: Loads behind obstacles have been shown to decrease significantly when compared those from bare-earth conditions, but these decreases cannot yet be quantified for general conditions.  Prediction becomes even more difficult when considering that some obstacles may be permeable to flow (vegetation), or may degrade over the course of the IE, changing loading.  This project will examine IE hazard intensities, loading, and fragility for structures located behind a single row of obstacles using (1) Scaling and theoretical analyses; (2) Computational fluid dynamics simulations; (3) Structural analyses; (4) Existing field and laboratory data.  Analyses will further consider the effects of obstacle degradation using fragility modeling of the obstacle itself. Results will consider uncertainties using surrogate modeling, which will both illuminate the major factors in loading and fragility uncertainties, and will suggest avenues through which results might be improved.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
Work on this project had the goal of quantifying the effects of vegetation on changing storm or tsunami inundation, loading to near-coast structures, and the resulting damage. Although reductions in damage had been anecdotally observed behind patches of vegetation, corresponding quantitative reductions in loading and damage have been hard to come by. This project used Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) and structural simulations (mostly) and partnerships with other researchers in laboratory experiments (lesser amount) to quantify loading and damage, and to relate these to measurable parameters of vegetation patches. 
In the project, CFD simulations of wave inundation and loading on a coastal building were performed and then compared with related simulations using the same conditions but with a patch of vegetation in front of the structure. An overall parameter was developed to describe quantitatively the properties of a vegetation patch, which was then related to changes in inundation and loading. Results showed strong decreases in maximum loads after a vegetation patch, with lower loads arising from larger values of the vegetation parameter. Conversely, water levels tended to increase around vegetation due to retardation of the runup flow. Surrogate models were then developed to relate wave and vegetation characteristics to maximum loads, giving a rapid way to estimate loading.
All of these results were input into structural models to estimate fragility for both masonry and reinforced concrete walls subject to runup loading. Outcomes for these case-study examples showcase that the protection offered by vegetation is substantial and can lead to a significant reduction in the vulnerability of the shielded structure. Comparison across different configurations for the vegetation (geometry, density) quantified the level of protection that is offered as function of the vegetation properties. It also revealed a channel effect that may occur in-between vegetation patches, which can lead to a relative increase in forcing on the shielded structures when density of vegetation increases.   
Collaborative work led by US Naval Academy researchers used laboratory tests of scaled mangroves to measure directly the changes to loading behind a mangrove patch. The geometries used were found to reduce maximum loads 11-65% when compared to the no-mangrove case. Dissipation and loading was found to be greater for short waves, while longer waves required a larger mangrove patch for the same relative load reduction. 
Overall, it was found that vegetation patches with appropriate properties can provide significant protection to structures subject to runup and inundation, and will in many cases decrease the likelihood of damage. In situations where the use of vegetated regions is appropriate and possible, they may become a viable method of planned defense for coastal communities.  


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Andrew B Kennedy
